p: The high efficacy of Nicotiana tabacum L. against H. contortus could be attributed to the presence of nicotine, a ganglion stimulant ( Bowman and Rand, 1980). Nematode muscles are known to contain excitatory neuromuscular junctions containing ganglion type nicotinic receptors with acetylcholine as their neurotransmitter ( Neal, 2020). Any ganglion stimulant would tend to activate theses neuromuscular junctions causing a spastic paralysis in the worms leading to their death and expulsion from the host ( Nouri et al., 2016). Among the reported plants with promising anti-haemonchiasis activity, L. viridiflorum leaves are rich in flavonoids and its anthelmintic action of egg hatching inhibition could be due to the effect on enzymatic activity and metabolic processes in helminthes ( Kerboeuf et al., 2008).
